Notes: Universities and secondary level school were already allowed to hold in-person classes. Strong restrictions are in place for in-person classes, including social distancing, hand-washing, etc...   Preschools are permitted to open as of March 15, 2021 for students aged 3 to 6  https://web.archive.org/web/20210313222429/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The restart of classroom activities for pre-school education, scheduled for March 15, has been suspended, due to the emergence of cases of contamination of COVID-19 by new variants of the SAR-COV-2 virus.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210321222121/https://governo.gov.ao/ao/noticias/suspenso-reinicio-das-actividades-do-ensino-pre-escolar/https://governo.gov.ao/ao/noticias/suspenso-reinicio-das-actividades-do-ensino-pre-escolar/

Country-Specific Information:     The majority of cases of COVID-19 are in the capital city of Luanda, but COVID-19 has been confirmed throughout the provinces.  Officials continue to monitor the individuals who have tested positive.? Please visit the Angolan COVID-19 Commission’s website for the most up-to-date case numbers.  The use of a face mask is required in all public areas, including anytime you leave your house or hotel room, while using public transport, and in all establishments.  Face masks are not required if you are operating a vehicle alone or exercising outside.  Individual and group exercise is permitted between the hours of 5a.m. to 9p.m.? Groups exercising together are limited to no more than ten people.? Everyone is encouraged to adhere to social distancing.  Health centers and hospitals are fully operational.  Restaurants are open from 6a.m. to 9p.m. for table service, and from 6a.m. to 10p.m. for takeout.? In person dining is limited to 50 percent capacity with no more than four guests per table.? Stores, including supermarkets, can remain open until 10p.m.? Museums and monuments, movie theaters, cultural and art fairs, libraries, and media centers are open but limited to 50 percent capacity.? Religious activities are limited to four days a week with no more than 50 percent capacity or 150 people and are limited to a maximum duration of 2 hours if held in enclosed spaces.  Recreational use of beaches and public swimming pools remains suspended.  Recreational use of boats is permitted, up to 50% of capacity.  Primary schools, secondary schools, and universities are permitted to hold in-person classes.? Preschools remain closed.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210328230552/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No change in policy   https://web.archive.org/web/20210313222429/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Travel in Angola  Travel in the country is possible, but requires a rapid COVID-19 test. Air passengers can undertake a rapid COVID-19 test at domestic airports. Test documentation will be checked at all provincial borders. Test results are deemed to be valid for 7 days. Passengers travelling for longer than 7 days will need to undertake further tests as necessary, to continue to move around the country.    The Angolan government has declared a “situation of public calamity” which imposes a number of restrictions and public health measures to limit the spread of the virus:    individuals are encouraged to stay at home and practise social distancing  face masks are compulsory in all areas outside your home or hotel room, including in private motor vehicles. Fines are imposed for non-compliance  restrictions are in place on travel into and out of Luanda province and the neighbouring province of Kwanza Norte    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210329182513/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/angola/coronavirus
No change in policy   https://web.archive.org/web/20210313222429/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Limited international air travel for selected countries is permitted for only citizens or residents of the country, humanitarian transport, medical emergencies, and diplomatic missions.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210321225107/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/455551/angola-authorities-maintain-covid-19-restrictions-as-of-march-16-update-19     Regular flights to Portugal, Brazil, and South Africa will resume from 12 March, with the updating of the measures of the Presidential Decree on the Situation of Public Disaster, already in force.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210321222915/https://governo.gov.ao/ao/noticias/taag-retoma-ligacoes-aereas-internacionais/

Testing prior to arrival and departure  From 16 January, all air passengers are required to undergo a rapid COVID-19 test immediately on disembarking the plane. This is currently free of charge, which is undertaken in a hangar at the airport, but can take time. Passengers arriving in Angola, should carry water and a refreshment in case there is a long wait.    Those receiving a negative result will be allowed entry and can continue through immigration. You will need to undertake compulsory self-quarantine for 10 days before undergoing a further COVID-19 test. Those receiving a positive COVID-19 result will go immediately into mandatory quarantine at a government facility for observation and further testing.    All passengers are required to show evidence of negative COVID-19 test completed 24 hours before departure from Angola.    Quarantine requirements  All air passengers arriving in Angola will need to undertake compulsory self-quarantine for at least 10 days once tested for COVID-19 on arrival. If you test negative, returning residents can quarantine in their own homes. Non-resident essential workers have to quarantine in a government or government-approved facility. The Angolan authorities will release you from quarantine once you have tested negative for coronavirus. You must spend at least 10 days in quarantine before being tested.    If you receive a positive COVID-19 test result on arrival in Angola, you will be required to enter mandatory quarantine in a government facility for observation and further testing.    On arrival, passengers with short-term and visitor visas can expect to have their passports retained by the Angolan authorities at the Immigration desk. Passports can be recovered at the end of the 10 day quarantine period, on presentation of a negative COVID-19 certificate at the SME Department in the Departures lounge.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210329181613/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/angola/entry-requirements

Angola received it's first batch of vaccines from COVAX on the 4th of March and has already jabbed 90 plus people. It's stated priority groups are as follows: health professionals, teachers, defense and security forces, and people with comorbidities. I've coded all of these individuals as three groups: the healthcare force, the ""essential"" workforce meaning teachers, defense services, and thirdly, those with co-morbidities.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210307204010/https://governo.gov.ao/ao/noticias/vacinados-primeiros-cidadaos-contra-covid-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210307204352/https://governo.gov.ao/ao/noticias/angola-preve-imunizar-mais-de-16-milhoes-de-pessoas/

Angola received it's first batch of vaccines from COVAX on the 4th of March and on the same day  a group of 92 people were vaccinated.   Priority groups include: health professionals, teachers, defence and security forces, and people with comorbidities.  In addition to the first batch of vaccines under the COVAX initiative, Angola received vaccines from the AstraZeneca company, of Indian origin, which will supply 12.8 million doses by the end of July.  https:/web/20210313223557/https://governo.gov.ao/ao/noticias/vacinados-primeiros-cidadaos-contra-covid-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210313223826/https://governo.gov.ao/ao/noticias/angola-preve-imunizar-mais-de-16-milhoes-de-pessoas/

On March 15th, the health authorities on Monday announced the vaccination against Covid-19 of 44,632 people, including health, education professionals, law enforcement and order and security forces, the elderly, and people with comorbidity.   The government official said that, on Monday 15th March 2021, 5,832 people had been immunized, among which 2,414 kindergarten teachers.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210322082520/https://www.angop.ao/en/noticias/saude/covid-19-vacinados-mais-de-40-mil-cidadaos/

With this first batch of vaccines, estimated at about 10 per cent of the country's first phase vaccine needs, the Government will immunize health professionals, vulnerable people and those with complicated comorbidities.  So we have key workers in terms of health professionals, vulnerable people and those with complicated comorbidities receiving the vaccine. And the vaccine being delivered is the AstraZeneca/Oxford vaccine.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210329190357/https://www.afro.who.int/news/angola-becomes-first-country-eastern-and-southern-africa-region-receive-covax-vaccines-0

As of March 8, restrictions implemented in Burundi to limit the spread of COVID-19 remain largely unchanged as compared with those in effect during early February. Melchior Ndadaye International Airport (BJM) is open, and all incoming and outgoing passengers must possess negative results from a COVID-19 test taken within 72 hours prior to travel. Travelers arriving in Burundi by air must quarantine for seven days. All travelers must take a test on arrival in Burundi and a second test after six days in isolation. Travelers will be isolated at facilities approved by authorities and will be transported to and from these sites by security forces. Any traveler who tests positive will be placed into quarantine for 14 days at a government-designated hotel, along with all persons traveling in their party.    All land and water borders are closed. Enhanced screening measures are in place at all ports of entry. Cargo and humanitarian flights are operational. The use of social distancing and facemasks are encouraged.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210322081927/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/452381/burundi-nationwide-covid-19-restrictions-remain-largely-unchanged-as-of-march-8-update-9  http://web.archive.org/web/20210322082419/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/burundi/entry-requirements

There is no income support in Burundi.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210322091219/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Country-Specific Information:    The situation in Burundi with regard to COVID-19 has remained relatively stable throughout the pandemic as compared with other countries in the region. Social distancing and masks are encouraged but not enforced by law and large gatherings can be seen particularly with family, religious and cultural events. There was no national lock down and it has been businesses as normal in many areas of society.  For example, soccer matches have continued, as have large-scale group exercises, parties, weddings, and other activities.  Burundians have stopped hugging and shaking hands to some extent, and many public venues have handwashing stations installed. Overall, stores have continued to be fairly well-stocked, with the exception of imported fresh produce, which was affected slightly due to the interruption of commercial flights, while locally grown produce remains largely available. Public schools have remained open as well.  Melchior Ndadaye International airport reopened on November 8, 2020.    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210322080552/https://bi.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No policy change

According to the UK government's website on travel to Benin Republic, entry visas are restricted. Entry and exit at border crossings is limited to “extreme necessity” and authorised in liaison with bordering countries.    The land border with Togo is closed.    Cotonou Cadjehoun International Airport has reinforced measures in place for visitors arriving in Benin. All arriving passengers must undergo mandatory COVID-19 testing - one test on arrival and a second test 14 days after the first negative test result. These tests are at passenger expense; fees are 100,000 FCFA (approximately £136) inclusive for two tests, payable to airlines at the time of booking flights. Passengers will be required to leave their passports with Immigration Police for 72 hours until the first test results are received.  Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322080407/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/benin/coronavirus

There is economic support for both formal and informal works as outlined in the IMF that was updated on March 4th.  ------  https://web.archive.org/web/20210307133630/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

No new measures were recorded. In the past, there was a health preparedness and response plan for 2020 (0.9 percent of GDP) and 2021 (0.7 percent of GDP), and (ii) a socio-economic response plan to support formal sector companies (0.9 percent of GDP) and vulnerable households—for the latter, through cash transfers, electricity and water bills subsidies, and urgent social projects (0.2 percent of GDP). All these can be found on the IMF's page on COVID 19 Stimulus. Please see:  https://archive.ph/OH1Ai

According to the US Embassy;  Effective January 26, all airline passengers traveling to the United States ages two years and older must provide either a negative COVID-19 viral test taken within three calendar days of travel or provide a positive test result and documentation from a licensed health care provider or public health official of having recovered from COVID-19 in the 90 days preceding travel. Passengers must also attest, under penalty of law, to have received a negative qualifying test or to recovery from COVID-19 and medical clearance to travel.   Airlines?must deny boarding to passengers?who do not?meet these requirements.???See the?CDC Proof of Negative Test Result page?to view the order,?complete the attestation,?and?to see?FAQ’s.  Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Benin? Yes, PCR tests are readily available. See the section “Entry and Exit Requirements” above for information on access to government-sanctioned testing.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes.  Humanitarian exemptions to this order will be granted on an extremely limited basis and will only be considered when the country of departure lacks adequate COVID-19 testing capacity. See the U.S. Department of State’s Testing Requirement page for information on limited humanitarian exemptions to CDC’s testing requirement. To submit information in support of an exemption, email ConsularCotonou@state.gov.  Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322081014/https://bj.usembassy.gov/info-covid19/

One year after the start of the pandemic in Benin, the COVAX initiative shipped 144,000 doses of the AstraZeneca / Oxford vaccine, licensed by the Serum Institute in India, to Cotonou on March 10, 2021.    This delivery is the first batch received by Benin thanks to the COVAX facility which aims to support the Government's efforts and ensure fair and equitable access to COVID-19 vaccination. In total, 792,000 doses of vaccines will be delivered to Benin through the COVAX initiative by May 2021.    The 144,000 initial doses of vaccines were received at Cardinal Bernadin Gantin International Airport by Minister of Health Benjamin Hounkpatin and members of the COVAX initiative, namely the UNICEF Representative and the WHO Representative, accompanied by the Resident Coordinator of the United Nations System in Benin.    Benin thus joins the list of African countries that have received their first doses of COVID-19 vaccine via the COVAX mechanism. This arrival constitutes a major step forward for Benin in its fight against the COVID-19 pandemic and a historic moment towards the objective of ensuring an equitable distribution of COVID-19 vaccines throughout the world, within the framework of what constitutes the largest vaccine purchase and supply operation in history.    “Benin is very happy to receive its first vaccines against COVID-19 through the COVAX initiative. Receipt of vaccines marks a turning point in the national response to the pandemic. We are confident that with these vaccines our efforts to protect the population against the virus will be strengthened. However, we must increase awareness so that communities continue to respect barrier gestures, even after the introduction of the vaccine, ”said Minister of Health Benjamin Hounkpatin.    “These vaccines from the COVAX initiative are the result of multilateralism and international cooperation aimed at making the COVID-19 vaccine a global public good. An important step remains to be taken, that of mobilizing the population for vaccination. I would therefore like to reiterate the commitment of the United Nations to support the Government to vaccinate as many people as possible as quickly as possible, so that no one is left behind, ”said the Resident Coordinator of the United Nations System in Benin Salvator Niyonzima .    “Vaccination saves lives every year by protecting children from serious illness. With the arrival of vaccines against COVID-19, it is a ray of hope that looms on the horizon because, among the targets to be vaccinated as a priority are those that ensure the right to health and protection for each child. Our thanks also go to all our donor partners who support us on a daily basis in this initiative, ”said UNICEF Representative Djanabou Mahondé.    According to Dr Mamoudou Harouna Djingarey, Acting Resident Representative of WHO, “WHO is delighted with the successful outcome of the negotiations and agreements that have taken place between the various United Nations agencies and international and national partners to provide States with that of Benin, the quantity of vaccines needed to save human lives against COVID-19. This is a historic step in solidarity and the race towards equitable access to anti-COVID-19 vaccines for low-income countries as advocated by the COVAX initiative which is to ensure an equitable distribution of global COVID-19 vaccines ”.    “This is the most ambitious pandemic response initiative in history, and we see an important milestone in our joint efforts now that Benin and other countries in Africa begin to roll out vaccines for their most vulnerable populations, ”said Dr Antoinette Eya Awaga, Country Manager of Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance. ""To ensure that the pandemic is behind us, we must maintain a sense of urgency and a spirit of partnership so that countries' immunization campaigns are successful, health systems recover and livelihoods be restored ”.    The vaccines transported to Benin with the support of UNICEF come from India. This first batch of vaccines will be administered to 70,000 front-line health workers and the most vulnerable, such as people over the age of 60 and people with co-morbidities. In total, 20% of the population is expected to benefit from COVAX vaccines.    A shipment of 145,000 syringes and 1,450 safety boxes, from a Gavi-funded stock from UNICEF's regional supply center in Dubai, was received on March 7, 2021.    Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322085142/https://www.gouv.bj/actualite/1208/    Also, Benin received this Sunday, March 21, 2021, 203,000 doses of the anticovid vaccine Coronavac from the Manufacturer SINOVAC, the result of Sino-Benin cooperation.    Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322085711/https://www.gouv.bj/coronavirus/flashinfos/

""""All travelers must present a negative COVID-19 PCR (nasal swab) test upon arrival in Ouagadougou.  The test result must be dated within five days of arrival and can be in English or French. Rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) or antibody tests are currently not accepted.  If a passenger does not arrive with a negative COVID-19 test, a rapid COVID-19 test will be performed at the airport, at a cost of 90,000 CFA (approximately 155 US Dollars) and the passenger will be detained until results are available.  All travelers are also required to present a negative COVID-19 PCR (nasal swab) test dated within five days to depart from Ouagadougou International Airport.""""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314032833/https://bf.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/""

Several measures have been taken under the revised budget, including: (i) lowering import duties and VAT for hygiene and healthcare goods and services critical to tackle COVID-19, and for tourism businesses; (ii) lowering other selected tax rates; (iii) delaying tax payments, and waiving late payment fines and penalties; (iv) suspending government fees charged on informal sector operators for rent, security and parking in urban markets; (v) lowering the licensing fee for companies in the transportation and tourism sectors; (vi) suspending on-site tax inspection operations; (vii) Donating food and providing assistance to households and local small businesses; (viii) supporting the water and electricity bills, including through cancelation, of the most vulnerable social groups; and (ix) securing adequate stocks of consumer products and strengthening surveillance of prices.  -----------  https://web.archive.org/web/20210318000808/https://bf.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210321171516/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/burkina-faso/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20210321171620/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

•	Is public transportation operating? Yes  •	Masks are required at all times on public transportation. Buses and vans operate at full capacity and do not always follow guidelines, so passengers should exercise extra caution when using public transportation.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315081040/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No measures to close public transport.    State of Public Emergency in place from September until the end of March with no changes in this policy in the most recent press release, see earlier gazetted guidelines:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210222203002/https://www.caab.co.bw/wp-content/uploads/Government-Gazette-Extraordinary.pdf

There is a nationwide curfew in place, which has been extended until 31 March - with no movement of people, except those with a movement permit (for essential services), from 10pm to 4am.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315080650/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/botswana/coronavirus

Curfew from 8PM to 4AM.     See the president's press release on 23 March, effective until the end of March:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210329164802/https://twitter.com/BWGovernment/status/1374450561852993541

•	Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Yes  •	Botswana is divided into 9 geographical zones (map available at gov.bw) and permits are only needed to travel between zones. Residents may travel within their zone without permits.  •	Permits for inter-zone travel may be acquired online at gov.bw and are restricted to essential travel. COVID-19 tests may be required at any time for those transiting zones. Tourism is considered essential travel for economic reasons, and Botswana residents may organize permit applications with a reservation confirmation from their destination lodging.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315081040/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Permits needed in order to travel between zones.    State of Public Emergency in place from September until the end of March with no changes in this policy in the most recent press release, see earlier gazetted guidelines:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210222203002/https://www.caab.co.bw/wp-content/uploads/Government-Gazette-Extraordinary.pdf

You must present proof of a negative COVID-19 PCR test performed no more than 72 hours prior to your arrival. After arrival, you will have to remain in contact with the local health authority for a period of 14 days for self-monitoring.   At Botswana border points, all travellers, including children, will be required to undergo an additional cost-free COVID-19 test to gain entry to Botswana. If the test is positive or you show COVID-19 symptoms, you may need to undergo 14 days isolation or quarantine at your own expense.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315080754/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/botswana/entry-requirements

All travellers arriving should have a valid 72 hour PCR negative test.    State of Public Emergency in place from September until the end of March with no changes in this policy in the most recent press release, see earlier gazetted guidelines:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210222203002/https://www.caab.co.bw/wp-content/uploads/Government-Gazette-Extraordinary.pdf

Key Policy Responses as of March 4, 2021  The government established a COVID-19 Relief Fund with a 2 billion Pula (about 1.1 percent of GDP) contribution from the government that will: i) finance a wage subsidy amounting to 50% of salaries of affected businesses (1000-2500 pula per month for a period of 3 months; ii) finance a waiver on training levy for a period of 6 months (150 million pula). The MoF also decided a tax deferral of 75% of any quarterly payment between March and September 2020 to be paid by March 2021.; iii) Build-up of fuel and grain reserves, as well as acquisition of relevant medical equipment and improvement of water supply (475 million Pula); iv) Fund a government loan guarantee scheme of 1 billion Pula (20% financed by commercial banks) for businesses that are tax compliant (including those who are not eligible to pay taxes/). Guarantee covers a period of 24 months with a max of 25 billion pula per borrower. Reduce the VAT refund period (from 60 days to 21 days).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315081515/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
There is a relief fund in place, but is mostly run on donations.     See Botswana COVID-19 portal:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210222204746/https://covid19portal.gov.bw/covid-19-relief-fund

The MoF also decided a tax deferral of 75% of any quarterly payment between March and September 2020 to be paid by March 2021.; iii) Build-up of fuel and grain reserves, as well as acquisition of relevant medical equipment and improvement of water supply (475 million Pula); iv) Fund a government loan guarantee scheme of 1 billion Pula (20% financed by commercial banks) for businesses that are tax compliant (including those who are not eligible to pay taxes/). Guarantee covers a period of 24 months with a max of 25 billion pula per borrower. Latest updates on official twitter account. There is also a COVID-19 online portal.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210201183209/https://covid19portal.gov.bw/ https://web.archive.org/web/20210222205426/https://www.gov.bw/about-covid-19

COVID-19 Testing:  •	Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Botswana? Yes  •	There is a current acute shortage of PCR test kit materials. As a result, almost all tests in Botswana are now rapid Antigen tests and citizens may have a difficult time accessing a timely PCR test.  •	If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? No  •	Antigen (rapid) tests are available at the international airports and major land border crossings. PCR tests are available for U.S. citizens at two locations: Sir Ketumile Masire Teaching Hospital and Diagnofirm Medical Laboratories, both in Gaborone.  •	Teaching Hospital PCR tests are 500 BWP and results can be slower than 48-72 hours as this is the main testing facility for everyone in country and is cheaper than Diagnofirm. Diagnofirm offers PCR tests for 999 BWP which are available in less than 24 hours. Antigen test costs range from 150 to 500 BWP. All testing is paid for by the patient. The Teaching Hospital price of 500 BWP is a price limit set by the Government of Botswana and is therefore partially subsidized.  •	Test results are delivered by text message/SMS. Expect delays in messaging even if the results are completed on time.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315081040/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Rapid specimen collection for testing for suspected cases.     See government website containing guidelines: https://web.archive.org/web/20210222205426/https://www.gov.bw/about-covid-19

Botswana has made an upfront payment to COVAX, the World Health Organization (WHO)’s vaccine arrangement, to acquire 940,800 vaccines under a two-dose regime, enough to cover about 20 percent of the population. In addition, Botswana has paid US$7.1 million to the African Vaccine Acquisition Task Team (AVATT) to secure more vaccine doses.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315081515/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Botswana received a consignment of the CoviShield Vaccine from India earlier in March. The Ministry of Health's facebook page announced the rollout on Friday the 26th of March, with group C (the elderly) as the priority.     See the vaccine self-registration portal:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210330090433/https://dhis2sms.gov.bw/vaccine/    See also an earlier government press release about the consignment in early March:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210330091016/https://twitter.com/bwgovernment/status/1369215961308553219    Refer to the facebook page of the Ministry of Health for more details:  https://archive.vn/6NBHY

Botswana received its first consignment of 33,600 AstraZeneca vaccines from the COVAX facility. This is the second consignment since receiving the CoviShield Vaccine from India earlier in March. The Ministry of Health's facebook page also announced the rollout on Friday the 26th of March, with group C (the elderly) as the priority. According to the US Embassy, testing is readily available and free.   The following facilities provide COVID-19 testing in Cameroon: Centre Pasteur and National Public Health Laboratory in Yaounde, and the Laquintinie Hospital in Douala. The Cameroon government has announced that these tests are free of charge.  Once the patient submits their sample, results are sent to him/her by email, text message, or physical copy within 24 hours unless otherwise specified by the testing facility.  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions to CDC’s requirement that all U.S. bound travelers present a negative COVID test, please review the following page: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/covid-testing-required-us-entry.html. Humanitarian exemptions to this order will be granted on an extremely limited basis and will only be considered when the country of departure lacks adequate COVID-19 testing capacity. To submit information in support of an exemption, email : yaoundeacs@state.gov.  Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308050348/https://cm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

All travelers above the age of 11 are required to provide proof of a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than seven days before arrival. Travelers must present a test administered by the Institut National de la Recherche Biomedicale (INRB) or a medical facility approved by the INRB. Public places and services  A curfew is in place from 18 December between 9pm and 5am. You should not be outside without justifiable reason (eg a medical emergency during these hours).    Wearing of facemasks is mandatory for anyone in public areas. This includes in public and private transport. The police will issue fines of 5000 Congolese Francs ($3) if masks are not worn.    DRC authorities have announced the following public health measures:    businesses, banks, restaurants and shops have re-opened in Kinshasa with social distancing measures in place.  places of worship, stadiums and performance halls have reopened with social distancing measures in place.  schools, colleges and universities are closed.  social enterprises eg bars and nightclubs remain closed  Public health measures can change at short notice and you should monitor local media for the latest developments.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308153330/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/coronavirus

Public places and services  Gatherings of more than 50 people are prohibited, with the exception of public markets, which are open on weekdays (except Wednesday) and Saturday.    Bars and nightclubs are closed.    Face masks must be worn in all public places.    The Republic of Congo authorities have mobilised defence and security forces to ensure compliance with the lockdown measures, at the entrance and exit of all cities across the country.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210315201653/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/congo/coronavirus

Movement Restrictions:    Is a curfew in place? Yes  A nationwide curfew is in place each evening from 9 pm to 5 am.  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No  Domestic travelers age 11 and older are required to present a negative COVID-19 test for travel between the provinces when departing from Kinshasa, Lubumbashi, Bukavu, Goma, and Kisangani. Where possible, the test must be taken within 7 days of travel.  Check with your airline about COVID-19 safety measures, testing requirements, and health requirements at your destination.      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210315202330/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Entry and Exit Requirements:    Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter? Yes  Is a negative COVID-19 test required for entry? Yes  Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? Yes  Is a negative COVID-19 test required for departure? Yes  DRC Requirements:  All arriving international travelers age 11 and older must arrive with proof of a negative COVID-19 test from within 3 days of their departure to DRC. Upon arrival, travelers age 11 and older must also submit to a COVID-19 test at the airport.  Travelers should register their information and pay for the test at INRBCOVID.com before they start their travel.  The cost of the required test is US$45 which can be paid in U.S. cash at the airport.  Following the sample collection at the airport, passengers must self-quarantine until they receive a negative test result via the website and/or SMS, generally within 24 hours.  All travelers must present a World Health Organization (WHO) card with proof of yellow fever vaccination.  U.S. citizens should travel with proof of health and medical evacuation insurance. Check with your medical evacuation insurance company on options should you fall ill in the DRC.  To exit the DRC, all passengers age 11 and older must present a negative COVID-19 test from the INRB or a laboratory approved by the Ministry of Health, from within 3 days prior to departure. The cost of the test through the INRB is US$30.  Visit INRBCOVID.com for information on testing in the DRC.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308152633/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/entry-requirements

Entry rules in response to coronavirus (COVID-19)  Entry to the Republic of Congo  All passengers arriving in the Republic of Congo by commercial flights should provide proof of a negative coronavirus (COVID-19) test undertaken within 72 hours upon entry, with the exception of children under 11 years of age. You should not use the NHS testing service to get a test in order to facilitate your travel to another country. You should arrange to take a private test.    Passengers who do not present a negative COVID-19 test upon entry will undertake a COVID-19 test at the airport, and need to self-isolate for 14 days, pending the results.    You should not use the NHS testing service to get a test in order to facilitate your travel to another country. You should arrange to take a private test.    Screening on arrival  Travellers entering the Republic of Congo may be subject to screening, including temperature checks.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210219183650/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/congo/entry-requirements

The government mentioned the plan to provide economic support to members of the vulnerable population. A grant of a flat-rate allowance of 200,000 households, at the rate of 50,000 CFA francs per household. The additional resources granted by the World Bank (US $ 20 million) and State funding of around 3 billion CFA francs should be sufficient to pay the planned allocation to 339,143 eligible households:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210214134108/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-11-fevrier-2021/

Healthcare in DRC  For contact details of English speaking doctors visit our list of healthcare providers.    Coronavirus testing is available at the following main towns:    Kinshasa  Matadi  Lubumbashi  Goma  Kolwezi  Mbandaka  There are a variety of testing facilities and the price starts from $45 USD.    If you think you have coronavirus symptoms, you should call DRC government healthcare services on 101, 109, 110. COVID-19 Testing    Are PCR tests available for U.S. citizens in DRC? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  COVID-19 testing is available in DRC at the traveler’s expense. Options include:  INRB(Official DRC Institute), Email: Info@INRB.net, Address: Av. De la Democratie No 5345, Gombe, Kinshasa. (Batetela Building, 1st floor; Intersection of Avenue Batetela and Boulevard du 30 Juin.  Search for “Pharmacie 30 Juin” on Google Maps.  They are located in the same building.)  No appointment required, cost $45, you must follow this process:  Go to inrbcovid.comto register online.  During registration scan and upload a copy of a travel document (passport) and the airline tickets.  Upon registration you will receive a confirmation ID that will be used to pay at the Testing Center and then get tested.  Results are only available in person, 24 hours after testing.  Hospital Du Cinquantenaire(Official INRB testing site), Phone: +243 844 430 396, Address: Ave Deliberation, Commune Kasavubu, Kinshasa  H&J Hospitals (Private hospital, home and office visits)H&J Testing location in Gombe (office visit): Pullman Kinshasa Grand Hotel4 Avenue Batetela, 9535, Price: $55, Call: 099-138 3675 to make the appointment. Then, via WhatsApp to that number, provide a copy of your passport bio, email address and phone number. *Results generally 24 hours later.H&J Testing location in Limete (main hospital): 1st Street Limete Industrial, 22309, Boulevard Lumumba. Price: $55, To Make an Appointment: Tel: 0813 531 861; Email: HJ POC Abhishek  Kapoor at abhishek.kapoor@hjhospitals.org. Wait times vary depending on the number of people being tested that day. *Provide a copy of your passport bio, email address and phone number.Result: the same day if testing performed before 12 pm. H& J Home Visit: To Make an Appointment: Tel: 0813 531 861; Email: HJ POC Abhishek  Kapoor at abhishek.kapoor@hjhospitals.org.*, A copy of passport along with your email and contact information isneeded to confirm the appointment.  Price: $55 + $40 for convenience fees.  Result: the same day if testing performed before 10 am  Centre Medical Diamant (CMD), by Appointment at CMD (no home visits). Address: 2366 Colonel Monjiba, Ngaliema (II Mercato Business center building).  To make an appointment:  Email CMD at k@cmd.cd (English or French) or call them at #0907 777 780 (French only).* Results and Certificate expected via email.  Consult CMD for current processing time, which varies from 24-48 hours.  Cost: $70  All airline passengers to the United States ages two years and older must provide a negative COVID-19 viral test taken within three calendar days of travel. Alternatively, travelers to the U.S. may provide documentation from a licensed health care provider of having recovered from COVID-19 in the 90 days preceding travel. Check the CDC website for additional information and Frequently Asked Questions.  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions to the U.S. requirement, please review the following page: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/covid-testing-required-us-entry.html  Humanitarian exemptions to this order will be granted on an extremely limited basis and will only be considered when the country of departure lacks adequate COVID-19 testing capacity.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210315202330/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Coding review:  Revising back to 0    C6 and H8 coding only mentions night time curfew    So changing H8 to 0 per the coding guidance that a nighttime curfew “will not affect the operation of Long Term Care Facilities or elderly residents, so really only significant curfews during the majority of daytime hours would warrant coding C6 as a 2, and an H8 as a non-zero value accordingly.”    Previous coding:  2G  Public places and services A curfew is in place from 18 December between 9pm and 5am. You should not be outside without justifiable reason (eg a medical emergency during these hours). Wearing of facemasks is mandatory for anyone in public areas. This includes in public and private transport. The police will issue fines of 5000 Congolese Francs ($3) if masks are not worn. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308153330/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/coronavirus Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308160828/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Not yet being put in arms, but the first wave of COVAX Astrazenica vaccines have been delivered, 24,000. Inoculation thought to begin March 19th.      ""Cape Verde on Friday received the first batch of 24,000 COVAX COVID-19 AstraZeneca vaccines and is set to commence its inoculation programme on March 19th, hoping to reach 70% of its population later this year...The prime minister said that soon another 80,000 doses of the vaccine from the same pharmaceutical company will arrive, and on March 15, 5,850 doses of Pfizer will arrive, also under the same international mechanism.    Asked about the fact that several European countries have suspended the administration of the AstraZeneca vaccine, the Cape Verdean leader said that there is no scientific evidence of a relationship between cases of strong blood clotting and its application.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210312105522/https://africa.cgtn.com/2021/03/12/cape-verde-receives-24000-astrazeneca-vaccines/

Public places and services  Markets have reopened as normal.    Restaurants with a terrace have reopened. A valid negative COVID-19 tests is compulsory for access to a restaurant. Cost of tests are 5000 CFA or approximately £7.00.    Gatherings of more than 30 people are banned, however, parliament and educational institutions are exempt from this limit.    All place of worship can only open one day a week. Places of worship with a maximum of 30 people have to observe the ‘sanitary protocol’ which includes compulsory wearing of masks, hand sanitisation, and social distancing.    Schools will close at 3pm each day to comply with general curfew. Hospital visits are forbidden without authorisation from medical authorities.    Bars, beaches remain closed.    Access to restaurants and places of worship is subject to presentation of negative PCR test.    Wearing of masks in public is compulsory from the age of 5 years old.      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308030837/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/gabon/coronavirus

Gabon-Specific Information    The prevalence of COVID-19 cases in Gabon has recently increased, and government restrictions have tightened. As of January 25, the government has extended the curfew hours to 20:00 to 05:00.  Beginning the evening of January 30, land borders were closed except for government-approved crossings.  The government is monitoring the situation closely and has warned it will impose strong restrictions again should the situation worsen appreciably.  Churches and indoor dining are currently open at a maximum occupancy of 30 people. Fines for exceeding the 30-person limit on gatherings will range from 100,000 to 5,000,000 FCFA.  The wearing of facemasks is obligatory in all public spaces, to include riding or driving in a vehicle with two or more persons inside. If driving alone, the driver is required to have a facemask to be used immediately upon exiting the vehicle.  Fines for not wearing a facemask will range from 25,000 to 200,000 FCFA.  Social distancing and other hygiene requirements continue.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210315140257/https://ga.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/coronavirus-update/

According to the UK government's page on travel to Gabon; gatherings of more than 30 people are banned, however, parliament and educational institutions are exempt from this limit.  All place of worship can only open one day a week. Places of worship with a maximum of 30 people have to observe the ‘sanitary protocol’ which includes compulsory wearing of masks, hand sanitisation, and social distancing. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322062754/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/gabon/coronavirus

Transportation Options    Are commercial flights operating?   Commercial air travel continues with three international flights per airline per week.  Crossing land and sea borders for commercial goods and services requires prior authorization.  Tourists are not permitted to arrive by land or sea.  Is public transportation operating? Yes  Masks are obligatory in all public transit vehicles. Taxis are operating at half capacity, limiting ridership to no more than 2 passengers per car.  Taxi buses are similarly limited in ridership.  In practice, however, many of these rules are ignored.      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308031805/https://ga.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/coronavirus-update/

Key Policy Responses as of March 4, 2021    FISCAL  The Amended Budget Law approved in end-June 2020 proposed the control of non-priority expenditure and redirects savings and development partners support of FCFA 73.9 billion (USD 138.1 million or 0.83 percent of GDP) to COVID-19 related spending. The government also plans to allocate additional FCFA 108 billion (USD 194.1 million or 1.2 percent of GDP) as an economic response, including through food stamps, electricity and water subsidies, direct support to SMEs and tax holidays. The Minister of Finance has created a fund available at their Caisse de Depots et Consignation (CDC) and designated a public accountant in order to facilitate disbursements of the health-related spending of that fund. An additional mechanism of around USD 375 million has further been announced to facilitate access to commercial banks financing for private (formal and informal) companies, including SMEs. The promulgated 2021 Budget Law allocates FCFA 3 billion (USD 6 million) for additional Covid-19 expenditures.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308034205/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Reopening of the economy. Since April 27, some of these measures were relaxed, including the full lockdown in Libreville. A second reopening wave started on July 1 with the reopening of commercial flights twice per week per company from Libreville and a reduced night curfew from 8pm till 5am. Since mid-August commercial flights were further relaxed to three flights per company per week departing from Gabon. Public schools reopened on November 7, 2020. Since early September, the test for domestic trips could be performed up to 14 days prior to departure. All passengers arriving in Libreville’s airport from abroad must show a negative test performed in the last five days. At arrival, they are once more tested by Gabonese authorities in the airport for posterior tracing. On October 10, a new round of relaxation of the preventive measures was announced, allowing restaurants and religious centers to resume activity and shortening the night curfew from 10pm till 5am. Such gradual reopening of the economy was based on a comprehensive-testing strategy with a capability of around 10,000 tests to be performed per day and with the equivalent of more than twenty-five percent of the population tested, making the country one with the highest rates of testing per capita of sub-Saharan Africa. The Gabonese parliament has also launched at the end of the first semester a Parliamentary Inquire Committee to investigate the quality and transparency of the Covid-19 expenditures by the government. The Ministry of Health is currently preparing a national vaccination strategy against the disease. At the same time an aggressive second wave of infections has hit the country and the preventive measures have been strengthened. The night curfew has been re-enlarged from 6 pm until 5am, causing business to close around 3pm. The capital, Libreville, has been put in confinement for domestic travelers and only two international flights per company can land in Gabon per week again. Masks became compulsory for the population above 5 years-old and restaurants and shops must demand a negative test from clients within the last seven days.      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308034205/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Gabon-Specific Information    The prevalence of COVID-19 cases in Gabon has recently increased, and government restrictions have tightened. As of January 25, the government has extended the curfew hours to 20:00 to 05:00.  Beginning the evening of January 30, land borders were closed except for government-approved crossings.  The government is monitoring the situation closely and has warned it will impose strong restrictions again should the situation worsen appreciably.  Churches and indoor dining are currently open at a maximum occupancy of 30 people. Fines for exceeding the 30-person limit on gatherings will range from 100,000 to 5,000,000 FCFA.  The wearing of facemasks is obligatory in all public spaces, to include riding or driving in a vehicle with two or more persons inside. If driving alone, the driver is required to have a facemask to be used immediately upon exiting the vehicle.  Fines for not wearing a facemask will range from 25,000 to 200,000 FCFA.  Social distancing and other hygiene requirements continue.      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308031805/https://ga.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/coronavirus-update/

The administration of the vaccine to citizens hasn't started but the vaccine is available in Gabon.

As part of the imminent start of the vaccination campaign against COVID-19, the Minister of Health, Dr. Guy Patrick Obiang Ndong visited, this Tuesday March 16, 2021, the vaccination centers of the University Hospital Centers of Libreville, d 'Owendo and the Jeanne Ebori Foundation in the presence of the President of the Scientific Committee of the Copil coronavirus, Pr. Marielle Bouyou Akotet.    It was for the member of the government to inquire about the level of preparation of these structures as a prelude  to the said vaccination campaign and the patient circuit.    In terms of organization, the Owendo University Hospital has set up a spacious room including two vaccination posts, three observation chairs and a cold room.    At the University Hospital of Libreville, there are five vaccination posts spread over two pavilions, a main one with two vaccination rooms, two observation rooms, a waiting room, a cold room and a data entry office and a second pavilion, in development course, which will consist of three vaccination rooms, a waiting room, an observation room and an entry room.    Finally, at the Jeanne Ebori foundation mother-child hospital, a large room with five vaccination and observation posts has been set up and is ready to welcome patients.    At the end of this visit, the Minister of Health expressed his satisfaction with the arrangements made by the three CHUs for the smooth running of the vaccination campaign against COVID-19.    It should be noted that the teams in charge of this vaccination will each be made up of anesthetists, senior anesthesia-resuscitation technicians (TSAR), psychologists, nurses, Red Cross volunteers and vaccination agents. previously trained.  Please see:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322071135/https://infocovid.ga/visite-des-centres-de-vaccination-dans/

A, B, C: AstraZeneca/Oxford vaccine  Ghana was one of the first countries to receive vaccines through COVAX. 600,000 doses were received on February 24 and they started to administer them to the public on March 2. The Health service has published vaccination site information in different districts around the country. A main goal of the COVAX initiative is to provide doses for at least 20% of countries' populations. Ghana aims to vaccinate 20 million Ghanians by the end of 2021. Due to the criteria above, I have coded Ghana as a 2. There is no evidence of cost for recipients; the vaccine was funded by the COVAX initiative.   ""So, from Tuesday, 2nd March, to Monday, 15th March 2021, the Ghana Health Service will begin deployment of the six hundred thousand (600,000) AstraZeneca vaccines, with persons in Groups 1 and 2 being the target of this first vaccination campaign. It will be conducted in forty-three (43) districts, which are the epi-centres of the pandemic in the country. They are twenty-five (25) in Greater Accra, sixteen (16) in Ashanti, and two (2) in the Central Region.""   ""Group 1 is categorised as “persons most at risk and frontline State officials”. It includes healthcare workers, frontline security personnel, persons with underlying medical conditions, persons sixty (60) years and above, and frontline members of the Executive, Legislature and Judiciary.  Group 2 is made up of other essential service providers and the rest of the security agencies.""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210307022840/https://presidency.gov.gh/index.php/briefing-room/news-style-2/1866-it-is-in-our-collective-interest-to-take-covid-19-vaccine-vp-bawumia    https://web.archive.org/web/20210306173631/https://presidency.gov.gh/index.php/briefing-room/speeches/1865-update-no-24-measures-taken-to-combat-spread-of-coronavirus    https://web.archive.org/web/20210307021132/https://ghanahealthservice.org/covid19/downloads/vaccine_administration.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210307020522/https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2021/03/04/971798030/ghana-greets-historic-vaccine-delivery-with-a-dose-of-skepticism

On February 26, 2021, in response to a recent uptick in COVID cases, the government reinstated a number of containment measures. According to the US Embassy, arriving passengers:  testing must be completed no more than 72 hours prior to arrival in Guinea or the traveler will be tested upon arrival and be required to quarantine for 14 days.  Arriving passengers with proof of a negative test within the 72 hours prior to arrival will not undergo any additional testing or quarantine in Guinea.  Arriving passengers with symptoms or who test positive for COVID-19 will be sent to a designated treatment center until two negative tests are completed. Please see:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322094321/https://gn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

All arriving and departing travellers must present the results of a negative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) COVID-19 test. Quarantine only applies to specific circumstances: arriving travellers with outdated test results, with symptoms, or who test positive for COVID-19 on entry will be sent to a designated treatment centre under quarantine until two negative tests are completed. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322094321/https://gn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

The country got free vaccines.   Guinea on Wednesday received a donation of 200,000 Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses from China as it seeks help from multiple sources to halt the spread of the coronavirus, foreign affairs minister Ibrahima Khalil Kaba told Reuters.    The West African nation of around 12 million is awaiting its first shipment of 864,000 doses from the global vaccine-sharing scheme COVAX, which started deliveries to developing countries last week.  Guinean authorities are also in talks to obtain 400,000 doses of Russia’s Sputnik V COVID-19, a health ministry official said last month.    Sixty doses of the Russian vaccine were previously provided on an experimental basis, with President Alpha Conde and some ministers among those inoculated.   Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322104842/https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-guinea-idUSL5N2L1637

Minister of Health Remy Lamah said Guinean medical staff, people in key positions, religious practitioners and elderly people over 65 will be among the first in line for vaccination. All travelers arriving from countries where new strains of the coronavirus have been identified – including the United States – may be required to undergo COVID testing upon arrival. Travelers must also comply with the current requirement to possess a negative PCR COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours prior to arrival into The Gambia. Individuals arriving without a negative test that complies with this requirement, or who tests positive for COVID-19 upon arrival, will be required to undergo mandatory quarantine at Gambian government-designated facilities, at the traveler’s own expense. Quarantined individuals should expect to be tested for COVID-19 by Gambian Health Officials upon arrival at quarantine facilities. Quarantined individuals should expect to stay up to 14 days in a quarantine facility, depending on their test results. Quarantined individuals are required to pay all costs associated with this quarantine period, and may also be expected to pay for any necessary COVID-19 tests. Those held at quarantine facilities are provided with basic shelter, food, water, and medical care. https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://gm.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Arriving passengers must present a negative PCR COVID-19 test, taken within 72 hours prior to arrival within The Gambia.  Those arriving without a test that complies with these requirements – including those with tests taken outside of this 72-hour window, or ‘rapid test’ results – will be subject to mandatory quarantine in Government of The Gambia-managed facilities:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329222209/https://gm.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

The government of The Gambia has approved Astrazeneca as COVID-19 vaccine for use.  On 3rd March Gambia has received its first shipment of 36,000 doses of COVID-19 vaccines through the COVAX Facility, less than a week after the Ministry of Health submitted the required documentation for the delivery of the vaccines to the country. The AstraZeneca vaccines were shipped by UNICEF on behalf of COVAX, from the Serum Institute of India (SII), and arrived at the Banjul International Airport late Tuesday night.  More shipments of COVID-19 vaccines and syringes are expected in the coming weeks.   The country plans to vaccinate frontline health workers, people who are 65 and above and those with co-morbidities in the first round of the campaign, Bittaye said. The start date of the vaccination drive hasn’t yet been confirmed, he said.    https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://gm.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/   https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.unicef.org/wca/press-releases/first-tranche-covid-19-vaccines-arrives-gambia-covax-initiative  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-03-03/gambia-set-to-start-vaccinations-after-covax-senegal-donations

'On 26 March 2021, the Government of Kenya confirmed that bars in the counties of Nairobi, Machakos, Kajiado, Kiambu and Nakuru are closed and that eateries and restaurants in the same counties will provide takeaways services only and will not serve alcohol. Bars, restaurants and eateries in all other counties would continue to close at 9pm (local time), but will be permitted to sell alcohol.'    Despite of the new strictions, '[p]ublic places, tourism and hospitality establishments, travel and tour companies, hotels and other accommodations, and recreation facilities are allowed to operate, provided they comply with Government of Kenya public health protocols, including 1.5 metre social distancing and the night-time curfew.  ...  Pharmacies and other shops selling essential products remain open, though business hours may be affected by the nationwide curfew.'    https://archive.vn/fc0R8
No change in policy.    https://archive.vn/fc0R8

On 26 March 2021, the Government of Kenya confirmed that '[t]he suspension of large gatherings, in person meetings of any nature, congregational worship, conferences and political events have been suspended in the counties of Nairobi, Machakos, Kajiado, Kiambu and Nakuru until further notice.  In other counties the maximum number of persons permitted to attend meetings or events has been capped at 15, permitted to attend funerals has been capped at 50, weddings capped at 30, with all in attendance expected to abide by Ministry of Health protocols.'    https://archive.vn/fc0R8
No change in policy.    https://archive.vn/fc0R8

Kenya rolled out vaccines in early March after received the first vaccines from the COVID-19 Vaccines Global Access facility – COVAX.  'The current vaccination plan only covers 30% of the population as this is what the government has been able to secure. Once more doses and funds become available, they will expand the target.  Healthcare workers in 47 counties are among those who will get the jab first. Frontline workers, including security personnel and teachers, are also on the priority list. [Healthcare worker and frontline workers are both counted as 'Key workers] ...  Vaccine rollout will be done in three phases. The first involves 1.25 million people and runs between now and June 2021.'    https://archive.vn/Zm4XU

'Kenya has offered free COVID-19 vaccines to all diplomats based there, including thousands of United Nations staff, even though it has not completed inoculating its own health workers, other frontline staff or elderly, drawing criticism from local medics.  ...  The government note said vaccinations would begin on March 23 and only accredited diplomats and their families were eligible.'    https://archive.vn/O6H7H
'NAIROBI (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - Kenya will let private hospitals charge for COVID-19 vaccinations and will not set a price limit on their cost...'    https://archive.vn/QRxBD
No change in policy.

Schools open on a rotational basis, adhering to Standard Risk-Based Guidelines. Lesotho returned to an amended purple level on 1 March.    See NACOSEC twitter page for latest updates:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315114415/https://twitter.com/nacosec/status/1366095087126593537/photo/1  See also UK travel advice: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315114427/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus

Schools and colleges are permitted to open on a rotational basis to reduce numbers on site and in school transport.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329061303/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus

Workplaces such as retail stores, grocery stores, cafes, salons, banks and communication companies open from 8AM until 6PM. Other businesses, private and NGO institutions permitted to operate with 50% capacity and staff under rotation. Lesotho returned to an amended purple level on 1 March.    See NACOSEC twitter page for latest updates:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315114415/https://twitter.com/nacosec/status/1366095087126593537/photo/1  See also UK travel advice:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315114427/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus

The government of Lesotho has decreased the lockdown alert to “Blue Alert (Level 2)” effective March 22, 2021. The return to Blue Level loosens restrictions on some public activities but maintains mandatory masks in public places and a nationwide curfew each day from 10:00 pm to 4:00 am. COVID-19 health and safety protocols must be followed at all times, including observance of guidelines for social distancing, sanitation and hygiene, and the use of appropriate personal protective equipment, like cloth face masks. Supermarkets, pharmacies, and most businesses can operate in line with safety protocols. Employees are instructed to work from home where possible.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329061628/https://ls.usembassy.gov/lesothos-new-directive-on-coronavirus-international-arrivals-now-asked-to-self-isolate-for-14-days/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329061303/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus

All initiations, sports events, political gatherings and demonstrations banned. Lesotho returned to an amended purple level on 1 March.    See NACOSEC twitter page for latest updates:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315114415/https://twitter.com/nacosec/status/1366095087126593537/photo/1  See also UK travel advice: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315114427/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus
Political rallies and other gatherings are banned.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210329061303/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus

All social and other gatherings banned. 50 person exceptions for weddings, PITSO for COVID-19 awareness and outdoor gyms. Lesotho returned to an amended purple level on 1 March.    See NACOSEC twitter page for latest updates:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315114415/https://twitter.com/nacosec/status/1366095087126593537/photo/1  See also UK travel advice: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315114427/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus
Social and family gatherings are not permitted.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329061303/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus

Restricted capacity on public transport: 11 passengers in a 15 seater, 15 passengers in a 22 seater etc. Lesotho returned to an amended purple level on 1 March.    See NACOSEC twitter page for latest updates:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315114415/https://twitter.com/nacosec/status/1366095087126593537/photo/1  See also UK travel advice: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315114427/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus

Public transport can now operate at full seated capacity. Masks must be worn at all times. Eating in the vehicle is prohibited.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329061303/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus

Curfew from 9PM to 5AM. Lesotho returned to an amended purple level on 1 March.    See NACOSEC twitter page for latest updates:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315114415/https://twitter.com/nacosec/status/1366095087126593537/photo/1  See also UK travel advice: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315114427/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus
Lesotho is under “Blue Level” restrictions. A curfew is in place from 10pm to 4am.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329061303/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus

There are no restrictions on interzonal or intercity travel within Lesotho. Lesotho returned to an amended purple level on 1 March.    See NACOSEC twitter page:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315114415/https://twitter.com/nacosec/status/1366095087126593537/photo/1    See also US embassy information for more clarity: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315120010/https://ls.usembassy.gov/lesothos-new-directive-on-coronavirus-international-arrivals-now-asked-to-self-isolate-for-14-days/

Movement Restrictions:  •	Is a curfew in place? Yes  Under Blue Alert (Level 2), the curfew will apply from 2200 until 0400 daily.  •	Are there restrictions on travel between districts? No  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329061628/https://ls.usembassy.gov/lesothos-new-directive-on-coronavirus-international-arrivals-now-asked-to-self-isolate-for-14-days/

Some land borders and Moshoeshoe I airport open. Open only for restricted groups: teachers and students crossing daily and registered entrepreneurs. Otherwise bans from arrivals still apply. Lesotho returned to an amended purple level on 1 March.    See NACOSEC twitter page for latest updates:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315114415/https://twitter.com/nacosec/status/1366095087126593537/photo/1  See also UK travel advice: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315114427/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus

Movement across the border is restricted to those providing essential goods and services, those with medical emergencies (with permits) and certain other limited categories.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329061443/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/entry-requirements

Public assistance plans in 2020, but no further announcements on income support.     See IMF policy tracker:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210315122129/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Public campaign in place, active on twitter and facebook. NACOSEC (National COVID-19 Secretariat) is better updated on social media than on official websites. Limited testing in place, private testing available to travellers.     See US embassy information:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210315120010/https://ls.usembassy.gov/lesothos-new-directive-on-coronavirus-international-arrivals-now-asked-to-self-isolate-for-14-days/

COVID-19 Testing:  •	Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Lesotho? YES  •	If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? YES  •	COVID-19 testing is available to travelers in Maseru at various private facilities. Results are usually available in 24 hours.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329061628/https://ls.usembassy.gov/lesothos-new-directive-on-coronavirus-international-arrivals-now-asked-to-self-isolate-for-14-days/

Government has announced its plan to vaccinate 1.4 million people by the end of 2021, but there is not yet evidence of on-the-ground vaccination. A  25 March 2021 - COVID-19 vaccine launch in Lesotho—health workers the 1st group vaccinated!  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329062311/https://www.afro.who.int/news/covid-19-vaccine-launch-lesotho-health-workers-1st-group-vaccinated  3 March 2021 - Lesotho received the 36,000 doses of the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine via COVAX, a multilateral vaccine initiative backed by the World Health Organization (WHO), according to the agency and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329081512/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/africa/2021-03/04/c_139782368.htm

Even though the government has already received the first batch of vaccine, rollout has not begun yet.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210308234321/https://reliefweb.int/report/mali/covid-19-vaccines-arrive-covax-facility-becomes-reality-mali    Vaccine: AstraZeneca

Mali received its first batch of vaccines against COVID-19 on 5th March, the first Sahel-Saharan country to receive shots through the COVAX initiative.  A plane carrying 396,000 doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine landed in Bamako where President Bah N'Daw and Prime Minister Moctar Ouane were among those waiting:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322142507/https://reliefweb.int/report/mali/covid-19-vaccines-arrive-covax-facility-becomes-reality-mali

All travellers have a negative PCR or negative antigen test within five days prior to arrival in Mauritania. Travellers should keep their test results with them throughout their travels because the test results can be requested by airline agents or immigration officials.   All passengers must isolate for 10 days.   https://web.archive.org/saved/https://mr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

""Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? Yes. Mauritanian medical staff be taking temperatures via thermal camera at all ports of entry. If a traveler has a fever, that traveler will immediately take either a PCR or antigenic test to determine if the person has a COVID infection. Furthermore, all passengers, regardless of nationality, over the age of 11 must have a negative COVID test prior to exiting Mauritania.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210323073129/https://mr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

As part of the restrictions, all activities will remain closed except for the police, port, airport, fire services, health, pharmacy, and security services. https://archive.ph/HJ3LX#selection-2605.0-2605.156  Effective March 10, 2021, the government of Mauritius has announced a nation-wide period of confinement until March 25thin response to COVID-19.  Supermarkets, shops, and bakeries will reopen subject to strict sanitary measures, including limited access through an alphabetical order system.  All schools, public places including beaches, shopping centers, and restaurants are closed until March 25th.  International flight arrivals have been suspended; however there are limited commercial departures to certain destinations.  https://archive.ph/7YQj1#selection-1817.72-1821.407

Effective March 10, 2021, the government of Mauritius has announced a nation-wide period of confinement until March 25thin response to COVID-19.  Supermarkets, shops, and bakeries will reopen subject to strict sanitary measures, including limited access through an alphabetical order system.  All schools, public places including beaches, shopping centers, and restaurants are closed until March 25th.  International flight arrivals have been suspended; however there are limited commercial departures to certain destinations.  Health regulations remain in place including temperature screenings, social distancing and mandatory face coverings.   https://archive.vn/9IRsP#selection-1877.71-1881.525

Effective March 23, 2021, the government of Mauritius has announced an extension to the nation-wide confinement until March 31st.  The re-opening of additional economic activities will start as from March 31.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210318001915/https://mu.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

COVID-19 Testing  Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Mauritius? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  COVID-19 tests are available at the C-Lab laboratory at Wellkin Hospital on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 09:00 to 12:00. Patients must dial 605-1000 to book an appointment.  Results are available within 48 hours.  Cost of Rs.2500 (approximately $60 USD) must be paid in full by the patient.  Visit Wellkin Hospital’s COVID-19 announcement (French) for additional information.  Test results are sent electronically, or patient can obtain a physical copy at Wellkin Hospital.  https://archive.vn/bf9eG#selection-1817.0-1851.96

A,B,C COVAXIN, Covishield  He pointed out that several athletes, artists and influencers were also vaccinated in other centres, and reminded that Government is doing its best to receive more vaccine doses so as to reach herd immunity at the earliest  https://archive.vn/DBMMo

GIS – 22 March 2021: Mauritius continues its national vaccination campaign with the COVAXIN vaccine, developed by Bharat Biotech in collaboration with the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), and today, 6 942 persons were successfully inoculated with it.  Dr Joomaye recalled that the Indian High-Commissioner, Mrs Nandini Singla, as well as the First Lady, Mrs Kobita Jugnauth, were among the first persons today to receive the COVAXIN vaccine at the Pandit Sahadeo Gymnasium in Vacoas. He pointed out that several athletes, artists and influencers were also vaccinated in other centres, and reminded that Government is doing its best to receive more vaccine doses so as to reach herd immunity at the earliest.  https://archive.vn/DBMMo

""Schools remain open per government policy. However, during the weeks of February 22 and March 1, the Teacher's Union of Malawi (TUM) protested the reopening of schools and some educators did not return to work until their demand for a COVID-19 risk allowance was granted. On March 9, the ministry of Education announced that they reached an agreement with the TUM officially calling off the strike, but many schools were still reporting closings. Per news stories on March 21, the government is yet to fulfill payment of the risk allowances to educators, and some are reporting that they will resume the strike on Monday, March 22.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210321235431/https://www.nyasatimes.com/confusion-over-suspension-of-teachers-strike-as-some-schools-remain-closed/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322000117/https://www.nyasatimes.com/government-risks-another-teachers-strike/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322000712/https://www.facebook.com/MalawiEducation/photos/a.540930199346395/3468181703287882/?type=3&eid=ARC8YHHLfAeClv9L07wmtsNspdaEjtRjPQvmcsBRH432pR-mOtcEKLP4JagEyOMJ06jFGUvEu60RTXKN&__xts__%5B0%5D=68.ARA_Ybp5S0temec8qxOvR48-K_fzs47omoWTO1Ufeq61-uNI_JOHJH3JyZiBQhyKnw0MvRO2BFn4T6LajnbaQ_8DjBHzwBAkl_CzdAp2A5Nd5UTCfC7wywM2tcMloZn6h4P-Hjy3G5yMunvO61kIOp2U-LyVkZBcybJ-tFiCXxl8A-qIO5LzL-nDgSTq0JUMzXn_xmJZmShI5zZP0yXi5wQZpgL-gdyDItEhAswO6p8baZTR6xBc0LlF1yZVh06UyExrZczVQ8Cha6yHoU97r10L7eB5ewK8Wil6hQttnVTldT1mSjyFIA""

Schools remain open. There are no news of teacher strikes restarting. There however have been incidents over COVID-19 vaccination and members of the public not wanting schools to be used as vaccination sites. A recent news story reports that the Ministry of Education has decided to reintroduce civics to school curricula which comes ""amid growing cases of mob justice, attacks on people with albinism and infightings as well as cultural rejections of the Covid19 vaccine, a thing that has sparked debates about patriotism and a need for civic education."" The implementation timeline of this policy remains unclear, but provides supporting evidence of schools remaining open.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210328032646/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Malawi%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Update%20-%2022.03.2021.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210328032837/https://reliefweb.int/report/malawi/un-malawi-covid-19-update-situation-update-no-38-22-march-2021    https://web.archive.org/web/20210328032111/https://allafrica.com/stories/202103260705.html

Per the US Embassy, ""A curfew is in place from 9pm to 5am. All markets must close at 5pm and all drinking establishments must close at 8pm. Hotels and lodges are operating but with strict COVID-19 measures. Wearing of face masks in all public places is mandatory, and those who do not follow these guidelines may face fines."" No evidence of a change in policy found on official government channels.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322004753/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/""

A curfew remains in place from 9pm to 5am until further notice. ""All markets must close at 5pm and all drinking establishments must close at 8pm.
