Minibuses are expected to limit passengers and require mask usage and some social distancing.""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322004753/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/""

Public transportation continues to operate. No change in the expectation to limit passenger capacity or enforce hygiene measures, it is unclear whether this expectation is being enforced.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210328034447/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Per the U.S. Embassy, ""A curfew is in place from 9pm to 5am. All markets must close at 5pm and all drinking establishments must close at 8pm.""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322004753/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/""

The 9pm-5am national curfew implemented in January 2021 continues until further notice. ""A curfew is in place from 9pm to 5am. All markets must close at 5pm and all drinking establishments must close at 8pm. Hotels and lodges are operating but with strict COVID-19 measures. Wearing of face masks in all public places is mandatory, and those who do not follow these guidelines may face fines.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210328034447/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/""

There are no updates from the government on movement restrictions. The US embassy reports that none are currently in place.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322004753/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/""
There are no new restrictions on internal movement. No change in policy.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210328034447/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/""

All arriving travelers are still required to present a negative COVID test result. No change in policy.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322004753/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/""

""Screening measures for incoming international travelers continue. """"All arriving passengers via air into the Republic of Malawi shall be required to produce a negative SARS Cov-2 PCR test certificate obtained within 10 days prior to arrival in Malawi. Any passenger without the said certificate will be denied entry. All arriving passengers will be asked to self-monitor for l4 days after which they will be followed up by Health Authorities.""""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210328034447/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210328041118/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/malawi""
No evidence of new income support for households found.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322013052/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19""

""There is no national income support being provided by the government.  Malawi's March 22 UN COVID-19 update reports that targeted support, partially funded by the government with international help, was given to some households in five districts. """"978 households in five districts were reached with cash transfers amounting to MK49,724,000 ($64,160) using crisis modifier fund following stormy rains, strong winds and flooding. This is supported by ECHO, UNICEF and government."""" Due to the limited number of households impacted, I am coding 0.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210328032646/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Malawi%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Update%20-%2022.03.2021.pdf""

There is no evidence that the maize subsidies have ended, however, the government has announced that they are increasing maize exportation by issuing licences. It will be good to track how this policy change affects the subsidies for locals.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322020145/https://www.nyasatimes.com/malawi-govt-says-maize-exportation-will-not-to-affect-food-security/""

""No evidence of a change in policy on the maize subsidies. """"The area planted to maize is estimated to have increased in 2021, further supporting the favourable production outlook. The upturn in maize sowings reflects the favourable weather conditions during the planting period and the roll-out of the Government’s Affordable Inputs Programme for the 2020/21 cropping season, which provided access to subsidized seeds and fertilizers for 3.8 million smallholder farmers.""""  """"The average price of maize per kg dropped by 4.7% from MK181.94/kg in first half of February to MK173.44/kg.""""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210328183158/https://reliefweb.int/report/malawi/giews-country-brief-malawi-25-march-2021    https://web.archive.org/web/20210328032646/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Malawi%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Update%20-%2022.03.2021.pdf""

""Malawi continues to have a coordinated COVID-19 public information campaign. There are daily COVID-19 updates posted by the Ministry of Health posted on social media and other government channels. The March 22 UN COVID-19 Update for Malawi reports that in collaboration with the Ministry of Information """"Over 4 million people reached with COVID-19 messages using multiple channels,  supported by Red Cross, WFP, ECHO, PMI SWISS and Save the Children.  ? 283,352 people were reached with COVID-19 messages through door-to-door  sensitisation in 13 districts supported by MRCS, WFP, ECHO and PMI SWISS.  Gaps and Needs  ? There is need to increase use of radios to complement work of volunteers and  other partners on the ground. Deliberately, intensify more use of airtime allocated.""""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210328043144/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2F    https://web.archive.org/web/20210328032837/https://reliefweb.int/report/malawi/un-malawi-covid-19-update-situation-update-no-38-22-march-2021

Testing continues to be available to individuals showing COVID-19 symptoms and travelers. It is important to note that early care seeking lead to positive treatment outcomes.""""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210328185005/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3722517194470435%3F__tn__%3DK-R    https://web.archive.org/web/20210328034447/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

""Wearing a mask in public places continues to be mandatory.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210328034447/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Malawi received 360,000 doses of the AstraZeneca COVID vaccine on March 5 through the COVAX programme. ""The Government of the Republic of Malawi has identified priority groups who will be among the first to receive the COVID-19 vaccine. These include health care workers, including those working in the private sector, who are at higher risk of COVID 19 infection than the general population due to the nature of their work, and more likely to be affected by COVID-19. Also included in phase one are police, immigration, Malawi Defence Force, teachers, prison warders, prisoners, those 60 years and above, and people with underlying conditions.""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322031324/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/UNICEF%20Malawi%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Report%20-%201-15%20March%202021.pdf

A,B,C:  AstraZeneca  The COVID 19 vaccine was launched in Malawi on 11 March 2021 in Zomba and Mzuzu districts concurrently, presided over by the State President and Vice President respectively. As of 15 March, 890 health workers and other frontline workers have been vaccinated. Malawi aims to vaccinate 20% of its population in the initial vaccination phase through the COVAX initiative.  ""On COVID-19 vaccination, let me inform the public that we are continuously working on  training more vaccination teams in the districts to ensure that more vaccination sites become  operational to increase access to the COVID-19 vaccine to the priority groups in the first  phase. As communicated on Thursday that, apart from continuing vaccinating the Health  Care Workers and other Social Workers, we rolled out vaccinating those with underlying  conditions (such as diabetes, asthma, hypertension) and those aged 60 years and above. It is important to note that the delivery platform remains the government and CHAM health facilities. The public is requested to contact their local/district health authorities for specific vaccination schedules for their area or district as more sites are being opened from tomorrow.  Let me request those coming for vaccination to bring their National Identity Cards while  those with underlying medical conditions to also remember to bring their health passport book (health profile). The public should be reminded that the COVID-19 vaccine is free of  charge and that it is voluntary. In the spirit of Covax, the vaccine is being distributed to all  corners of the country to allow for equitable access. Let us all wait for our turn.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322035053/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3702864499769038    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322035650/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3702163413172480%3F__tn__%3DK-R    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322031324/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/UNICEF%20Malawi%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Report%20-%201-15%20March%202021.pdf

""A,B,C:  AstraZeneca  COVID 19 vaccination was launched in Malawi on 11 March 2021.   Ministry of Health update on march 26: """"I would like to commend the public for the overwhelming response to the call to get  vaccinated especially for those targeted in this first phase. The response gives hope to the  COVID-19 fight in our country. On the overall, the rolling out has been smooth although in  some vaccination sites, we observed long queues due to high numbers of people coming to get vaccinated against the available staff. There were also some information gaps in some communities especially in the rural areas. In view of this, the Government through the Presidential Task Force on COVID-19 has allocated additional resources to assist in vaccination roll out. These resources will help to address the bottlenecks currently being observed. As we are working on these challenges, I would like to appeal for patience as we will ensure that everyone targeted in the first receives the vaccine.    Once again I would like to thank those that have made the excellent decision to get vaccinated. This is very commendable since fighting the COVID-19 pandemic is a collective effort. Let me also request those that are not eligible to receive the vaccine in the first phase, to patiently wait for their turn which will be communicated in due course. My request for those not eligible is to desist from going to the vaccination sites now to give opportunity to the elderly and those with co-morbidities to be vaccinated since COVID-19 tends to be more severe in these categories of people. The public should be reminded that the COVID-19 vaccine is free of charge and that it is voluntary.""""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210328193331/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3716961151692706%3F__tn__%3DK-R    https://web.archive.org/web/20210328192921/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3720073904714764%3F__tn__%3DK-R

No change in policy found. Hygiene and stay at home measures apply equally across all age groups. However, the elderly are a priority group for vaccination. Vaccine rollout started on March 11.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322035053/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3702864499769038    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322035650/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3702163413172480%3F__tn__%3DK-R    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322031324/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/UNICEF%20Malawi%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Report%20-%201-15%20March%202021.pdf""

If a person is confirmed as having tested positive for COVID-19, an authorised person must establish the names of persons who were or might have been in contact with the confirmed case. An authorised person must trace and monitor all persons considered to be contacts with a confirmed case; all persons are subject to COVID-19 testing. No change of policy in 25 February amendment of Public Health Regulations, effective until 31 March.     See the government gazette announcing the amendment:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322185305/https://mhss.gov.na/documents/119527/828815/AMENDMENT+OF+PUBLIC+HEALTH+COVID-19.pdf/e5842462-8d59-4c6e-86df-fe7fec89921f

The government has paid N$29,272,320 (US$1,626,240) to acquire vaccine doses enough to vaccine 20 percent of the population through the COVAX Facility; and signed a Financial Commitment Agreement for the remaining US$9,096,780.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308090339/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The government has paid N$29,272,320 (US$1,626,240) to acquire vaccine doses enough to vaccine 20 percent of the population through the COVAX Facility; and signed a Financial Commitment Agreement for the remaining US$9,096,780.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308090339/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The target populations include frontline health care workers, Community Health Workers, persons who are between 18 to 59 years, persons in close settings and those operating cross-border transportation, employees at Points of Entry, Police Officers,  Journalists, members of the diplomatic corps, Mining and fishery sector employees,  religious and traditional leaders, people with disability, minorities and refugees.     This is in accordance to Phase 1 of Namibia's vaccination plan and the vaccine administered is the Sinopharm SARS-CoV-2 Vaccine.    See the Minister of Health's statement on 16 March ""On the Occasion of the First Consignment of the Covid-19 Vaccine"":   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322193104/http://www.namibia-botschaft.de/images/stories/Aktuelles/Government/Consignement_of_Covid-19_Vaccines_MoHSS_160321.pdf

In public transportation, Operators shall ensure adequate spacing in between passengers.  Operators shall ensure frequent cleaning and disinfection of parts of the vehicle frequently handled by passengers and drivers such. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315024220/https://covid19.ncdc.gov.ng/media/files/Coronavirus_Disease_COVID19_Health_Protection_Regulations_2021.pdf

Operators shall ensure adequate spacing in between passengers. Operators shall ensure frequent cleaning and disinfection of parts of the vehicle frequently handled by passengers and drivers such as doors and window handles/buttons, steering wheels and dashboards. Operators shall encourage passengers to frequently perform hand hygiene. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322045948/https://covid19.ncdc.gov.ng/media/files/Coronavirus_Disease_COVID19_Health_Protection_Regulations_2021.pdf

?Travel between Kigali and other provinces and districts is not permitted, except for essential services and tourism (tourists must possess a negative COVID-19 test result).  Travelers, including drivers, traveling to tourism entities within Kigali and other provinces and districts are required to complete and submit movement requests through the Tourism Movement Facilitation Form found here. Travelers are also required to send copies of negative COVID-19 test results to visitrwanda@rbd.rwat least 24 hours prior to the trip.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210315130931/https://rw.usembassy.gov/health-alert-covid-19-information/
No policy change

Arriving travelers are required to self-quarantine at home for seven days after leaving the transit hotel. Travelers may also extend their stay at the designated quarantine hotel for this seven-day period. At the end of this period, travelers will receive a text message inviting them to a designated test site for a final test that will be performed free of charge prior to being released from quarantine.  All travelers arriving in Rwanda are required to have a negative COVID-19 certificate. The only accepted test is a SARS-CoV2 Real Time Polymerase (RT-PCR) performed within 72 hours prior to departure for Rwanda. All other forms of COVID-19 tests are not permitted.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210315130931/https://rw.usembassy.gov/health-alert-covid-19-information/
No policy change

S. citizens should consult the Rwanda Biomedical Center’s (RBC) for information about all testing requirements, to include arrival and departure.   PCR tests can be booked online through Irembo, found here. PCR tests cost $50 (or RWF 47,200). Payment is required for all U.S. citizens. Online payment is available through the scheduling website. PCR test results are generally delivered within 48 hours via text message (results only) and through the RBC’s COVID-19 Test Results Portal here. Passengers departing Rwanda are required to print out the travel certificate available through the COVID-19 Test Results Portal and hand carry them in order to enter the airport for departure.  RBC offers rapid antigen testing without appointment at 42 accredited private hospitals/clinics throughout Rwanda. Rapid antigen tests cost $10. A complete list of accredited private clinics offering this service is found here. Rapid antigen test results are available shortly after the sample is taken and are delivered in person.  If a traveler’s test result is positive for COVID-19 (even if asymptomatic) while in Rwanda, they will be treated as indicated in the National COVID-19 Management Guidelines until they have fully recovered. All treatment is at the expense of the traveler.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210304095728/https://rw.usembassy.gov/health-alert-covid-19-information/
No policy change

Vaccinations will be free of charge and voluntary and are being delivered by Covax   The vaccination is expected to be done in phases. In the first phase, the vaccine will go to front-line workers in healthcare including but not limited to those working in treatment centres and Intensive Care Units (ICUs). This phase will also see the vaccination of people above 65 and those whose immunity is weak and is likely to easily be compromised like those with cancer, diabetes, HIV and other serious diseases.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210223001542/https://www.pmnewsnigeria.com/2021/02/15/rwanda-begins-covid-19-vaccination-for-health-workers-others/   https://web.archive.org/web/20210128052530/https://www.newtimes.co.rw/news/unpacking-rwanda-plan-distribute-covid-19-vaccine

C1 – 0  Schools remain open. Link is a communication to students and parents from the International School of Dakar, describing their safety measures. https://web.archive.org/web/20210208233859/https://us16.campaign-archive.com/?u=4695e649f2734dd576711ac26&id=f469a96cfb

On 8 January, the Interior Minister announced that for the Dakar and Thiès regions all public gatherings are prohibited including at hotels, bars, beaches, sports grounds, theatres and public spaces. Consequently, many bars and other public venues are closing. Religious sites are open. Restrictions are changing rapidly; you should follow instructions given by the authorities.  Restaurants, casinos, places of worship, private beaches and markets are permitted to operate while maintaining social distancing measures and facial coverings.     https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/senegal/coronavirus
There is no change in the status until 19 March. A source for 19th March has been added for further reference.

As of 19th March all public health measures in Dakar and Thies have been lifted. There is no curfew in place.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210322211828/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/senegal

Restaurants, casinos, places of worship, private beaches, sporting events and markets are permitted to operate while maintaining social distancing measures and facial coverings. https://web.archive.org/web/20210330064230/https://sn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

As of January 7, the Government of Senegal has instituted restrictions in the regions of Dakar and Thies including bans on all public meetings, private gatherings (including weddings, baptisms and large religious gatherings), and gatherings at hotels, concert halls, bars, cafes, beaches, markets, sports fields, dance clubs, and weekly markets.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://sn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No requirements

A mandatory nightly curfew between 9pm and 5am (local time, GMT) came into effect for the regions of Dakar and Thiès on 6 January. During curfew hours, everyone must stay at home or indoors, except for essential government service workers. The motorways between the international airport and Thiès and between the airport and Mbour are closed between 8pm and 6am.  The Government of Senegal has advised that the airport will remain open and existing flight schedules will not change. People can still travel to the airport during curfew if they are passengers arriving and departing or the driver (no other people accompanying passengers are allowed). All of these people must carry a copy of their passport and plane ticket, which will allow for movement to the airport or to their accommodation. If you are arriving into Senegal at the airport in curfew hours, you should contact the person or taxi company you have arranged to collect you in advance to make sure they can still access the airport and have all the necessary paperwork.  There is currently no restriction on travel between regions, and authorisation is not needed to travel between regions. Internal flights have also restarted. Masks must be worn at all times in public areas and when travelling, including in a private car if there are two or more people in the car.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/senegal/coronavirus
No change from previous data

No restrictions in place

•  All travelers to Senegal over the age of two years must present an original COVID-19 test certificate showing a negative result. The test must occur within five days of entry into Senegal. The results must be from a PCR test (not a rapid test) and be issued by a laboratory approved for such testing or a recognized international health organization.  Travelers transiting Senegal must also show such proof if they will be present in Senegal more than 24 hours or wish to exit the airport.   •  Verification of testing compliance will be undertaken by the airline prior to departure.  Passengers without a negative COVID-19 test may not be permitted to board.   •  All travellers to Senegal may also be required to complete a passenger location form for public health officials, in accordance with recommendations from the International Civil Aviation Organization.  The form will be collected on arrival. The form is available for preview and download here.   •  The Government of Senegal has implemented restrictions that impact entry into Senegal for certain foreign nationals.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://sn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No change from previous data as public health measures were in place

Public places and services  Due to an increase in COVID-19 case numbers, new measures were introduced on 3 February 2021. Hotels, shops and restaurants are open but subject to strict social distancing, even if it is not consistently observed. Businesses which attract a crowd, including bars and nightclubs, are closed, as are schools and universities. Social gatherings, including sporting events, weddings and funerals, are banned.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210322111929/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/south-sudan/coronavirus
No policy change

Officials in South Sudan have issued orders to extend the ongoing partial lockdown through at least April 3 to curb the spread of COVID-19. Existing restrictions remain unchanged under the new directives. The following notable measures are in place through April 3:    Individuals must wear facemasks in public places. Penalties will apply for noncompliance.    All social and religious gatherings are banned until further notice.    All schools will remain closed, except classes scheduled for examinations.    Private and public sectors to make provisions allowing nonessential staff to stay home on paid leave or have staff on alternate shifts.    Public transport will operate at a maximum of 50-percent capacity.    Restaurants and cafes are open but are subject to strict hygiene and social distancing measures.    Bars and nightclubs will remain closed.    International TravelDomestic and international flights are operational. Incoming international travelers arriving at Juba International Airport (JUB) require South Sudan's National Taskforce permission before entering the country. Permitted travelers must present a negative COVID-19 test result from a screening taken within 96 hours before arriving in South Sudan. All incoming travelers are subject to a 14-day quarantine or self-isolation. Travelers and airline operators must adhere to preventive measures, including wearing protective facemasks and social distancing. All aircraft must undergo disinfection after arrival.    The nation's land borders have reopened; however, cross-border movement remains mostly limited due to neighboring countries' restrictions.    Authorities could reimpose, extend, further ease, or otherwise amend any restrictions with little-to-no notice depending on disease activity.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210322113137/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/451216/south-sudan-authorities-extend-covid-19-related-partial-lockdown-through-april-3-update-10
No policy change

Entry rules in response to coronavirus (COVID-19)  South Sudan has reopened its land borders but all passengers should check restrictions in place from neighbouring countries.    Coronavirus (COVID-19) certificate  To enter South Sudan, you must have a certificate showing you are free from coronavirus, issued no more than 72 hours ahead of your journey, and endorsed by a reputable medical provider. You will also need to self-isolate for 14 days on arrival.    You should not use the NHS testing service to get a test in order to facilitate your travel to another country. You should arrange to take a private test.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210322102324/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/south-sudan/entry-requirements
No policy change
There is currently no income support in South Sudan.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210322120455/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
No policy change
No information on debt/contract relief.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210322120455/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
No policy change
No information found stating otherwise.
No policy change

Healthcare in South Sudan  If you think you have COVID-19 symptoms, you should self-isolate and report any suspected case to the nearest health facility.    Testing capacity in South Sudan is extremely limited and results are subject to significant delay.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210322111929/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/south-sudan/coronavirus
No policy change
There is contact tracing but it is limited.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210322122509/https://moh.gov.ss/single_daily_report.php?report=March+20th+Update.pdf
No policy change

Officials in South Sudan have issued orders to extend the ongoing partial lockdown through at least April 3 to curb the spread of COVID-19. Existing restrictions remain unchanged under the new directives. The following notable measures are in place through April 3:    Individuals must wear facemasks in public places. Penalties will apply for noncompliance.    All social and religious gatherings are banned until further notice.    All schools will remain closed, except classes scheduled for examinations.    Private and public sectors to make provisions allowing nonessential staff to stay home on paid leave or have staff on alternate shifts.    Public transport will operate at a maximum of 50-percent capacity.    Restaurants and cafes are open but are subject to strict hygiene and social distancing measures.    Bars and nightclubs will remain closed.    International TravelDomestic and international flights are operational. Incoming international travelers arriving at Juba International Airport (JUB) require South Sudan's National Taskforce permission before entering the country. Permitted travelers must present a negative COVID-19 test result from a screening taken within 96 hours before arriving in South Sudan. All incoming travelers are subject to a 14-day quarantine or self-isolation. Travelers and airline operators must adhere to preventive measures, including wearing protective facemasks and social distancing. All aircraft must undergo disinfection after arrival.    The nation's land borders have reopened; however, cross-border movement remains mostly limited due to neighboring countries' restrictions.    Authorities could reimpose, extend, further ease, or otherwise amend any restrictions with little-to-no notice depending on disease activity.      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210322113137/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/451216/south-sudan-authorities-extend-covid-19-related-partial-lockdown-through-april-3-update-10
No policy change
The coronavirus vaccine is not yet available to citizens in South Sudan.
No policy change

Travel in South Sudan  An official government curfew is in force across South Sudan from 10pm to 6am. There are also some restrictions on public transport and inter-state movements. Passengers are required to wear face masks.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210322111929/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/south-sudan/coronavirus
No policy change

Payment arrangements for taxpayers facing cash flow problems, waiver of penalties and interest for old tax debts. The price of fuel reduced twice and planned increases in water/electricity prices postponed.    See IMF's tracker for policy responses (https://archive.vn/hgyyZ).

Revenue measures to mitigate the impact of the virus include: (i) taxpayers projecting losses will file loss provisional returns and no payment will be required; (ii) extension of returns filing deadlines by 3 months before penalties kick-in; (iii) payment arrangements for taxpayers facing cash flow problems; (iv) waiver of penalties and interest for older tax debts if principal is cleared by the end of September 2020; and (v) up to E90 million (0.13 percent of GDP) in tax refunds for SMEs that have complied with tax obligations, retain employees, and continue to pay them during this period.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322074813/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Eswatini has joined the COVAX Facility through which the country will secure vaccine doses to cover 20 percent of the population, of which 108,000 doses of AstraZeneca vaccine are expected in early March, and the remaining balance will arrive in 2021Q2. Government has further ordered 2 million doses from the Serum Institute of India and 237,328 doses from the AU, both expected to arrive in 2021Q2. The Eswatini National Immunization Technical Advisory Group (ESWANITAG) was appointed to provide scientific recommendations during the introduction of new vaccines and the implementation of immunization strategies.  In FY21/22 the government has budgeted E200 million to procure vaccines for Eswatini's entire population.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322074813/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

New guideline for visitors  http://web.archive.org/web/20210314144837/http://tourism.gov.sc/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Seychelles-Visitor-Travel-Advisory-4-March-2021.pdf    With immediate effect all visitors from any part of the world who have been vaccinated and are able to show  proof that they have taken the complete dose of the vaccine (the two doses) and that two weeks have elapsed  after the second dose will be allowed to enter Seychelles. However, they must provide a valid certificate of  vaccination authenticated by the local public health authorities from their country of origin and must also have  a negative PCR test taken 72 hours prior to travel. They will also be allowed free movement throughout their  stay in Seychelles.

The National Assembly has allowed the Central Bank to provide (i) a limited credit to government up to SCR 500 mill, preferably through purchase of securities, and subject to central bank Board approval; and (ii) extending the maturity of credit to commercial banks to 3 years. In May, a credit facility was established to assist commercial banks with emergency relief measures to support small- and medium-sized enterprises and another credit facility to support large enterprises was established. The two lines provide 70 percent and 50 percent support respectively. As of January 7, 11.89% of SCR500 mill allocated for MSMEs and 10.23% of SCR750 mill allocated for large enterprises has been used. On October 29, CBS extended the credit facilities until May 16, 2021 and June 20, 2021 respectively.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210201212038/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Entry rules in response to coronavirus (COVID-19)  Entry to Chad  Airports have re-opened for commercial flights. All passengers from the UK are banned from entering Chad until further notice due to the new COVID-19 variant.All international travellers need to present a negative COVID-19 PCR test certificate dated no more than 72 hours prior to arrival in Chad.    If you enter Chad and are planning to stay for 7 days or more, you will need to surrender your passport, quarantine at home for 7 days and take a COVID-19 test on the seventh day. Passports will be returned upon presentation of the COVID-19 test receipt. If you’re staying in Chad for less than 7 days you will not be need to quarantine.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308184644/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/chad/entry-requirements
Per the US State Department, land borders are restricted.  https://td.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No income support given.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308152023/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

FISCAL  Financing for COVID-19 health-related expenditures are estimated at CFAF 42 billion (0.8 percent of non-oil GDP), which are being implemented under a national contingency plan. Key measures include: (i) training of medical and technical staff, (ii) purchase of necessary medical equipment, (iii) construction of seven health centers in remote areas, (iv) construction of three mobile hospitals, and (v) securely managing entry points. Additionally, the capacity of Farcha Hospital in N'Djamena is going to be expanded and the hiring of additional health workers is in process. The authorities have also decided on a package of fiscal measures to help businesses weather the shock: (i) for SMEs, the authorities will, among other things, reduce by 50 percent the business license fees and the presumptive tax for 2020, (ii) tax breaks such as carryforward losses and delays in tax payments will also be examined on a case-by-case basis, (iii) clearance of domestic arears of about CFAF 110 billion owed to suppliers, (iv) a subsidy planned to the agricultural sector (0.3 percent of non-oil GDP), and (v) the simplification of the import process for food and necessity items, including health equipment, and tax exemptions for these items. Measures were also taken to alleviate the hardship on households, including (i) temporary suspension of payments of electricity and water bills for the lifeline consumption, as well as (ii) Replenishment of the national food distribution program (Office National de Sécurité Alimentaire, ONASA) (0.5 percent of non-oil GDP), (iii) the National Assembly adopted a new law on May 11 that establishes a Youth Entrepreneurship Fund (0.6 percent of non-oil GDP), (iv) payment of all death benefits due to deceased civil and military agents, indemnities and ancillary wages owed to retirees and payment of medical expenses for civilian agents and defense and security forces (0.1 percent of non-oil GDP), and (v) the national assembly adopted the law on September 26 that establishes the solidarity fund for the vulnerable population amounting to CFAF 100 billion. The 2020 supplementary budget, which includes the COVID-19 measures, was enacted by the Parliament in August.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308152023/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Policy still in place.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308185602/https://td.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210301011556/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/chad/coronavirus

COVID-19 Testing    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Chad? Yes.   If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes.   COVID tests can be obtained in one of the Chadian hospitals entitled to carry out the PCR test. The PCR test costs 15,000 FCFA (approximately USD $30).   The test result is typically printed and the hard copy is usually available the next day.   For information on limited humanitarian exemptions, please review the following page: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/covid-testing-required-us-entry.html.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308185602/https://td.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

""The 26-year-old resident of Tanzania's semi-autonomous islands of Zanzibar said the existence of Covid-19 had begun to resonate with many Tanzanians following the passing of Zanzibar's Vice President, Seif Sharif Hamad, who died in February after contracting the virus.  Hamad was open about his illness, which he made public three weeks before his death.  ""People now wear masks and wash their hands frequently. I think this is motivated by the recent loss of our vice president,"" Khamis said.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210323073547/https://www.cnn.com/2021/03/20/africa/john-magufuli-tanzania-covid-legacy-intl/index.html

""Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Tanzania? Yes. Testing is available through Government of Tanzania laboratories.  The details of testing (including test type and performance characteristics) have not been made available nor independently verified.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? No. There are increasing reports of test results being significantly delayed and some clinics no longer offering pre-travel testing. Many people also receive inconclusive results and are asked to repeat the test after several days. Travelers have tested positive upon arrival in foreign destinations following negative COVID-19 tests in Tanzania prior to departure.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210318004936/https://tz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No change.

""The Tanzanian government has not released aggregate numbers on COVID-19 cases or deaths since April 2020. https://archive.vn/E2HLz  All visitors to Zambia must have proof that they have tested negative for COVID-19 in the 7 days before their arrival. Visitors are responsible for monitoring their condition for 14 days after arrival, and should report any occurrence of COVID-19 symptoms to medical authorities. There is no requirement for visitors to self-isolate.

Quarantine Information  Are U.S. citizens required to quarantine? No  As long as travelers to Zambia apply for entry to the country with a negative COVID-19 test conducted within the previous seven days, a mandatory 14-day quarantine will not be enforced.  https://archive.ph/Xv7b8#selection-2233.0-2247.185

Zambia’s borders are open, but under tight screening.  Tourist and business visit visas are available in advance and on arrival in Zambia.  All visitors to Zambia must have proof that they have tested negative for COVID-19 in the 72 hours before their arrival. Visitors are responsible for monitoring their condition for 14 days after arrival, and should report any occurrence of COVID-19 symptoms to medical authorities. There is no requirement for visitors to self-isolate.  https://archive.vn/5e8NQ#selection-625.0-633.335

Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?  Yes.  Zambia has implemented limited screening upon arrival at the international airport in Lusaka.  The screening entails completing COVID-19 risk assessment form and may include using no-touch thermometers (“thermo-scanners”) to check body temperature.   Symptomatic individuals will be required to self-isolate for 14 days and may be asked to submit samples for additional COVID-19 testing.  https://archive.vn/jVXo6#selection-2173.0-2179.387

https://archive.ph/zIUF0   Health Minister Jonas Chanda says Government is finalising the detailed modalities of the choices of vaccines to be used and the operationalisation of the programme to be approved by Cabinet soon in the coming days.

A,B,C   She says cabinet has approved that the vaccine will priorities people above the age of 65, including those with chronic illnesses as they are at high risk of death.  Ms. Siliya says others that will be prioritized include health frontline workers, police, security traditional leaders, clergy and immigration officers as these are taken as the most essential to maintaining core societal functions.  She says marketeers, traders including bus and truck drivers involved in cross-border business, will also be prioritized in view of the environment they work through.  https://archive.vn/0G4Rx#selection-1057.0-1065.166

Lusaka that 13 vaccines that have been proven to be effective will be available, noting that only COVAX and astrazeneca will be administered to citizens by government.  The Permanent Secretary stated that other approved vaccines out of the 13 will be administered to citizens through private partners that have shown interest.

The Government of Zimbabwe requires all new arrivals to the country to present a negative COVID-19 test result issued within the previous 48 hours.
